title: 1993 Daytona 500
text:
The 1993 Daytona 500, the 35th running of the <a href="Daytona%20500">event</a>, was held February 14 at <a href="Daytona%20International%20Speedway">Daytona International Speedway</a> in <a href="Daytona%20Beach%2C%20Florida">Daytona Beach, Florida</a> as the first race of the <a href="1993%20NASCAR%20Winston%20Cup%20Series">1993 NASCAR Winston Cup season</a>. <a href="Dale%20Jarrett">Dale Jarrett</a> won the race.
Summary.
<a href="Kyle%20Petty">Kyle Petty</a>'s <a href="Felix%20Sabates%23NASCAR">No. 42</a> won the <a href="Pole%20position">pole</a>, putting a Petty on the <a href="Daytona%20500">Daytona 500</a> pole for the first time since <a href="1966%20Daytona%20500">1966</a>, and only the second time ever. Kyle was also the first <a href="North%20Carolina">North Carolina</a> driver to win the 500 pole since <a href="Benny%20Parsons">Benny Parsons</a> in <a href="1982%20Daytona%20500">1982</a>. His father <a href="Richard%20Petty">Richard</a> waved the <a href="Racing%20flags%23Summary">green flag</a> in the first <a href="Sprint%20Cup%20Series">Winston Cup</a> race held since his retirement.
The start.
The first lap was led by <a href="1993%20NASCAR%20Winston%20Cup%20Series%23Rookie%20of%20the%20Year">rookie</a> <a href="Jeff%20Gordon">Jeff Gordon</a>, who was the youngest winner of a <a href="Gatorade%20Duels">Gatorade 125-mile qualifier</a> on Thursday. Shortly after this, <a href="NASCAR%20on%20CBS">CBS</a> <a href="Sideline%20reporter">reporter</a> <a href="Chris%20Economaki">Chris Economaki</a> said that <a href="NASCAR%20Rookie%20of%20the%20Year">Rookie of the Year</a> is an award he would be almost assured of. Engine failures for <a href="Dick%20Trickle">Dick Trickle</a> and <a href="Jimmy%20Hensley">Jimmy Hensley</a> (the latter would crash in Turn 1 in his substitution for the injured <a href="Jimmy%20Means">Jimmy Means</a>) brought out the first two <a href="caution%20flag">caution flag</a>s in the first 15 laps.
Mid-race summary.
Over the next 110 laps, <a href="Dale%20Earnhardt">Dale Earnhardt</a>, <a href="Ken%20Schrader">Ken Schrader</a>, and <a href="Kyle%20Petty">Kyle Petty</a> would lead the majority of the laps, with <a href="Jeff%20Gordon">Jeff Gordon</a> and <a href="Bobby%20Hillin%20Jr.">Bobby Hillin Jr.</a> leading a handful of laps as legitimate leaders. <a href="1990%20Daytona%20500">1990 winner</a> <a href="Derrike%20Cope">Derrike Cope</a> and <a href="Harry%20Gant">Harry Gant</a> also led several of these laps, but they had pitted under the early <a href="Racing%20flags%23Summary">yellows</a> to stretch their fuel runs.
Meanwhile, two-time winner <a href="Bill%20Elliott">Bill Elliott</a> dropped out of the race on lap 99, the victim of overheating in his #11 <a href="Ford%20Thunderbird">Ford Thunderbird</a>.
Closing stages.
<a href="Dale%20Earnhardt">Dale Earnhardt</a> was the leader on Lap 130 when <a href="Wally%20Dallenbach%20Jr.">Wally Dallenbach Jr.</a> brushed the Turn 4 wall. <a href="Sterling%20Marlin">Sterling Marlin</a> and <a href="Michael%20Waltrip">Michael Waltrip</a> were lined up behind him, and when Marlin backed off, Waltrip tagged him and sent him into a spin. Marlin caught air as he spun by <a href="Joe%20Ruttman">Joe Ruttman</a>, who was coming to pit road to retire with engine failure. 5 laps after the restart, <a href="Rick%20Wilson%20%28racing%20driver%29">Rick Wilson</a> and <a href="Bobby%20Hamilton">Bobby Hamilton</a> collided on the backstretch. Approaching 50 laps to go, <a href="1991%20Daytona%20500">1991 Daytona 500</a> winner <a href="Ernie%20Irvan">Ernie Irvan</a> was turned into the wall exiting Turn 2, eliminating a possible winner. The first major wreck happened when <a href="Dale%20Earnhardt">Dale Earnhardt</a> touched <a href="1992%20Indianapolis%20500">1992 Indianapolis 500</a> winner <a href="Al%20Unser%20Jr.">Al Unser Jr.</a> (competing in his only <a href="Winston%20Cup%20Series">Winston Cup Series</a> race). His <a href="Hendrick%20Motorsports">#46</a> <a href="Chevrolet">Chevrolet</a> crashed into the <a href="Junie%20Donlavey">90</a> of <a href="Bobby%20Hillin%20Jr.">Bobby Hillin Jr.</a>, who spun into the path of polesitter <a href="Kyle%20Petty">Kyle Petty</a>. Both had a heated verbal exchange, Hillin reportedly was telling Petty he had no brakes, but both were victims of circumstances. With 31 laps to go, <a href="Derrike%20Cope">Derrike Cope</a> and Waltrip touched in Turn 2. Waltrip spun down into <a href="1989%20NASCAR%20Winston%20Cup%20Series">1989 Winston Cup Champion</a> <a href="Rusty%20Wallace">Rusty Wallace</a> and sent him into a horrific series of flips and rollovers in the grass. A little more than minute later, <a href="Ken%20Squier">Ken Squier</a> reported that Wallace came on the radio to <a href="pit%20stop">crew chief</a> <a href="Buddy%20Parrott">Buddy Parrott</a> and said, "I'm okay."
The finish.
By this time, <a href="Hut%20Stricklin">Hut Stricklin</a> and <a href="Sterling%20Marlin">Sterling Marlin</a> presented themselves as contenders. <a href="Dale%20Earnhardt">Earnhardt</a> led from the restart, only to be passed briefly by <a href="Dale%20Jarrett">Dale Jarrett</a>. The <a href="Richard%20Childress%20Racing">#3</a> was soon in the lead again, as he was pursued by the <a href="Chevrolet%20Lumina">Chevrolets</a> of Jarrett and <a href="Jeff%20Gordon">Jeff Gordon</a>, and the <a href="Ford%20Thunderbird">Fords</a> of <a href="1986%20Daytona%20500">1986 Daytona 500</a> winner <a href="Geoff%20Bodine">Geoff Bodine</a>, <a href="Hut%20Stricklin">Hut Stricklin</a>, <a href="Mark%20Martin">Mark Martin</a>, and <a href="Morgan%20Shepherd">Morgan Shepherd</a>. The "<a href="Dale%20Earnhardt">Dale</a> and <a href="Dale%20Jarrett">Dale</a> Show" commenced as Jarrett passed Earnhardt in the tri-oval as they took the <a href="Racing%20flags%23Summary">white flag</a>. As the leaders exited Turn 2, the <a href="CBS%20Sports">CBS Sports</a> producers told <a href="Ken%20Squier">Ken Squier</a> and <a href="Neil%20Bonnett">Neil Bonnett</a> through their headsets to let <a href="Ned%20Jarrett">Ned Jarrett</a> to "call his son Dale <a href="Checkered%20flag">home</a>". In response, Jarrett called the finish thus:
"Come on, Dale! Go, baby, go! All right, come on! I know he's got <a href="Throttle">it</a> to the floorboard; <a href="Dale%20Jarrett">he</a> can't do anymore! Come on! Take 'er to the inside! Don't let 'em get on the inside of you comin' around this turn! Here he comes, Earnhardt; it's the "Dale and Dale Show" as we come off Turn 4! You know who I'm pulling for, it's Dale Jarrett. Bring her to the inside, Dale! Don't let <a href="Dale%20Earnhardt">him</a> get down there! He's gonna make it! Dale Jarrett's gonna win the <a href="Daytona%20500">Daytona 500</a>!!!"
The next weekend at Rockingham, Ned reportedly apologized to Earnhardt for his obvious show of bias, to which an understanding Earnhardt replied, "I'm a daddy too."
